tweets.content:
My DMs are flooded with questions about @rustlang ğŸ¦€ resources so here it is!
Hereâ€™s a quick spotlight series: one post for each creator, their X handle + YouTube channel + what theyâ€™re best for.

Jon Gjengset
X: @jonhoo
YouTube: Jon Gjengset
Best for: Deep dives into Rust internals, async, concurrency, and the legendary â€œCrust of Rustâ€ series. If you want to master advanced Rust concepts, start here.

Rust Nation UK
X: @RustNationUK
YouTube: Rust Nation UK
Best for: Full conference talks, workshops, and interviews with top Rust developers. Great for keeping up with the Rust community and latest trends.

Semicolon
X: @shivansh7201
YouTube: Semicolon
Best for: Beginner-friendly Rust tutorials and hands-on coding walkthroughs. Ideal for absolute beginners.

Rustfully
X: @rustful
YouTube: Rustfully
Best for: Short, focused Rust tutorials perfect for bite-sized learning and quick tips.

Orhun ParmaksÄ±z
X: @orhunp
YouTube: Orhun ParmaksÄ±z
Best for: Rust shorts, CLI tools, and productivity hacks. Great for quick learning and inspiration.

Harkirat Singh
X: @kirat_tw
YouTube: Complete Rust Bootcamp
Best for: Full-length Rust bootcamp (6+ hours, Hindi/English mix). Perfect for new devs and anyone who wants a structured, hands-on marathon.

Solandy
X: @HeyAndyS
YouTube: Solandy
Best for: Solana-specific Rust tutorials, especially for DeFi and NFT use cases.

Rust Planet
YouTube: Rust Planet
Best for: Practical Rust projects and ecosystem exploration.

Rust Videos
X:@rustlang
YouTube: Rust Videos
Best for: Official Rust community curation conference talks, meetups, and lectures from all over the world.

Copenhagen Rust Community
YouTube: Copenhagen Rust Community
Best for: Community-driven channel with talks from Copenhagenâ€™s Rust meetups and events.

Code to the Moon
X: @CodeToTheMoons
YouTube: Code to the Moon
Best for: Rust explained simply ideal for those who want to see code in action.

Francesco Ciulla
X: @FrancescoCiull4
YouTube: Francesco Ciulla
Best for: Wide-ranging dev content, including Rust, with a focus on making tech accessible and fun.

Jeremy Chone
X: @jeremychone 
YouTube: Jeremy Chone
Best for: Rust, backend engineering, and system design.

Dario Lencina
YouTube: Dario Lencina
Best for: Practical Rust and systems programming; helpful for those coming from C/C++ backgrounds.

Trevor Sullivan
X:@pcgeek86
YouTube: Trevor Sullivan
Best for: Automation, DevOps, and using Rust for scripting and tooling.

Rust Programming Tutorials Playlist
YouTube: Rust Programming Tutorials
Best for: Step-by-step Rust tutorials for beginners.

Rust Nation UK Playlist
X: @RustNationUK
YouTube: Rust Nation UK Playlist
Best for: Curated talks and workshops from Rust Nation UK events.

Thanks to all these individuals and communities for creating such valuable content and sharing their knowledge with the Rust and Solana community.
Save/bookmark for later will keep updating as I find more gems. Tag your favorite creators if I missed anyone!

tweets.content: github.com/anshuman008/Custoâ€¦
tweets.author: anshu_code

tweets.content:
Imagine holding a private key with 15+ SOLâ€¦ and still not being able to spend it! 

It was a WSOL token account and I wondered how can an ATA even have a private key?

- ATA = PDA (off-curve) â†’ deterministically derived from (owner, mint) â†’ no private key exists
- Custom token accounts can be on-curve (keypair) â†’ they look like wallets but are just SPL token accounts

- In both cases, the owner field points to a wallet 
- Transfers require the owner walletâ€™s signature, not the token account keypair

So holding the token accountâ€™s private key â‰  spending control :)

Code + explanation on github ğŸ‘‡

tweets.author: anshu_code

tweets.content:
Many folks asked me if Rust is mandatory to start building on @solana  :) 

Answer: No
You can do 80%+ of things with just TypeScript and client side solana (prefer TS over JS).

Just learn:

- Solana account model & PDAs
- How transactions land on Solana
- Basics of Solana runtime
- Using Solana SDK (solana/web3.js)
- A little about Jito transactions

Then you can simply move into building:

â†’ Wallet extensions (Solana SDK)
â†’ Trading bots on DEX / launchpads (Anchor IDLs)
â†’ Integrate with any contract
â†’ Indexers (gRPC + protos)
â†’ Arbitrage bots (Kamino + RPC/gRPC)
â†’ Payment gateways
â†’ Tokens, NFTs, collections (Metaplex / Candy Machine)
â†’ DeFi projects

Most Solana products expose TS SDKs + Solanaâ€™s own solana/web3.js docs are amazing!

tweets.content: helius.dev/blog/alpenglow
tweets.author: anshu_code

tweets.content:
Going to sleep after diving into Solanaâ€™s Alpenglow upgrade from a great Helius article. Itâ€™s replacing Proof of History making things way faster & cheaper by moving voting off chain. Super impressive!  

But I still wonder will moving votes off chain risk more centralization? 

 Key points:  
- Finality: 12s â†’ ~150ms (near instant) 
- Off-chain voting = less congestion, faster consensus 
- Rotor = 1 hop block broadcast 
- Lower costs â†’ more validators 
- Simple 400ms block times, no cryptographic clock wait 

Link ğŸ‘‡

tweets.author: anshu_code

tweets.content:
Itâ€™s 7:30 AM and Iâ€™m finally going to sleep :) 

Spent the night deep diving into ShredStream insane speed boost over gRPC.

- About 100ms to 200ms faster
- Mid-slot data
- Access before the block is even complete

I thought gRPC was the fastest turns out ShredStream is way quicker.

Just finished writing a Rust ShredStream listener + parser (using protos for decoding)

Now I just need a premium gRPC provider that supports ShredStream for an end-to-end test.

Until thenâ€¦ good night :D

tweets.author: anshu_code

tweets.content:
TEEs vs zk-SNARKs

â†’ TEEs: Hardware-based, super fast, relies on trusted machines.
â†’ zk-SNARKs: Math-based, no hardware needed, fully verifiable.

Two paths to keep your data private on-chain - which side are you on?

tweets.content:
Hereâ€™s mine Web3 â†’ Solana â†’ Fullstack Blockchain Developer Roadmap

JavaScript / TypeScript â†’ Async/Await â†’ Fetch API / WebSockets

â†’ Blockchain Basics (Wallets, Keys, Signatures, Transactions)
â†’ Cryptography (ECDSA, Hashing, Ed25519)
â†’ Token Standards (ERC-20 / SPL) â†’ NFT Standards (ERC-721 / Metaplex)
â†’ Choosing a Chain (Ethereum vs Solana) â†’ Why Solana (Speed, Fees, Parallel Execution)
â†’ Client-Side Dev with solana/web3.js â†’ Wallet Adapters (Phantom, Solflare,Backpack)
â†’ Reading On-Chain Data â†’ Sending Transactions â†’ Token Transfers
â†’ SPL Token Program â†’ Associated Token Accounts â†’ Metadata Program
â†’Use client side libraries Build simple dApps or wallet extensions for practice
â†’ On-Chain Indexing (Helius, RPC/Webhooks)
â†’ Try to understand others contract transactions like pumpfun and raydium on explorers
â†’ Use prebuild launchpad sdks and make a simple trade bot using solana libraries solana/web3js and solana/spl-tokens
â†’ Rust Fundamentals â†’ Solana Program Architecture
â†’ Anchor Framework Basics â†’ Program Accounts â†’ PDA & Seeds
â†’ Testing Contracts (Mocha, Anchor Tests) â†’ Local Validator & Devnet
â†’ Cross-Program Invocations (CPI) â†’ Sysvars â†’ Rent
â†’ Fullstack dApp (React / Next.js + Anchor + web3.js)

â†’ Advanced Solana:
   â€¢ Jito / MEV Protection
   â€¢ Lookup Tables
   â€¢ Transaction Bundling
   â€¢ Parallel Execution & Priority Fees
   â€¢ Alpenglow

â†’ Tokenomics & Launchpads (Pumpfun, Raydium, Coinflict)
â†’ NFT Mints & Candy Machine v3 â†’ Auction House Program
â†’ Deployment: Solana CLI â†’ Mainnet
â†’ Monitoring & Logging (Solana Explorer, Sig Verify, RPC Health)
â†’ CI/CD for dApps & Programs
â†’ Infra: Docker â†’ Kubernetes â†’ GPU Nodes (for AI-integrated dApps)
â†’ Cloud (AWS/GCP) for RPC & Indexers

tweets.author: anshu_code

tweets.content:
Story Time:

I met a friend in the first year of college â€” a naturally talented coder. He had been coding since Class 11, and by the time we entered our first year, he already knew all the core programming concepts: loops, functions, data structures, OOP â€” everything. While the rest of us were still learning how to write a basic "Hello World" program, he was already solving college-level assignments with ease.

Itâ€™s been 5 years since then. With 7 years of non-stop coding experience under his belt, youâ€™d expect him to be working in a top tech company or building innovative products, right?

But no.

Heâ€™s currently working as a college teacher, earning â‚¹20,000 per month â€” the same job he joined last year. Heâ€™s not involved in any major projects, no startups, no open-source contributions, no tech community activities. He spends his time helping students with assignments, taking classes, and thatâ€™s it.

Itâ€™s surprising. A guy with that level of coding knowledge, someone who lives in VS Code, is now stuck in a routine job with no technical growth or exploration.

It just goes to show â€” skill alone isnâ€™t enough. Without direction, ambition, and real-world application, even the most talented people can end up underutilized.

tweets.content:
ğŸš€ Just merged v1-improvements to the @Live24_Fun backend!

âœ¨ 11 commits of pure optimization:

I realized a transaction can contain multiple instructions â€” like 4 buys, or a create + multiple buys bundled together.

So I built dynamic parsing to handle all instructions, not just single-level ones.

 - Dynamic instruction parsing

  - Hybrid DB calls: sequential for token creation, concurrent for trades

  - Refactored monolithic logic into clean, reusable helpers

Better performance, cleaner code, and more robust parsing :)

thanks to @kirat_tw â€” putting their backend optimization lessons into real-world action!

tweets.content:
ğŸ§µ/ Day 194 of building  Web3 startup from my dorm.

Iâ€™m a 4th-year student, full-stack dev, and I'm building something like @Live24_Fun.

No sleep. No funding. Just vision, code & chaos.

Hereâ€™s what itâ€™s really like building in public: ğŸ‘‡

Some days I feel like a genius.
Most days I feel like an imposter.
But I show up anyway.

- Code,
- test, 
- break.
- Repeat. 
- Learn. 
- Ship.

Web2 taught me structure. 
Web3 taught me freedom.

Itâ€™s not easy.
Itâ€™s not stable. 
But itâ€™s mine.

If you're a dev thinking about building â€” start now.
You donâ€™t need permission. 
Just commit & deploy.

tweets.author: anshu_code

tweets.content:
From March 2025 - May 2025 As a part of  @solanaturbine cadet,
I've learned a lot and written a few commonly used Anchor smart contracts with end-to-end tests:

1. Bonding Curve (github.com/prince981620/bondâ€¦)
- Pump Fun like Bonding Curve contract with CPI to Raydium CPMM POOL.
- Includes multiple instructions: create token, swap tokens, withdraw, sync native SOL (convert SOL to WSOL), and migrate liquidity to Raydium after bonding completes.

2. NFT Market Place (github.com/prince981620/nft-â€¦)
- Contract where user can list their NFT and another user can buy it

3. AMM (github.com/prince981620/amm-â€¦)
- Automated Market Maker with Constant Product Curve Algorithm.
- Users can deposit or withdraw token pairs to create or close liquidity pools and receive liquid staking tokens.
- Others can swap tokens from the created pools.

4. Escrow (github.com/prince981620/escrâ€¦)
- A simple contract where a user can lock SPL tokens, and another user can swap by transferring the required amount to the creator's account.

5. Vaults (github.com/prince981620/vaulâ€¦)
- A minimal contract to create a vault PDA for locking native SOL or SPL tokens, with support for deposits and withdrawals.

If you have any Project Idea or any opportunity/ Opening in Rust, Anchor, Solana smart contract . feel free to DM ğŸ™‚
